PGFed: Personalize Each Clientâ€™s Global Objective for Federated Learning

Jun Luo1 â€ƒMatias Mendieta2 â€ƒChen Chen2 â€ƒShandong Wu1,3,4,5
1 Intelligent Systems Program, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA

Abstract

Personalized federated learning has received an upsurge of attention due to the mediocre performance of conventional federated learning (FL) over heterogeneous data. Unlike conventional FL which trains a single global consensus model, personalized FL allows different models for different clients. However, existing personalized FL algorithms only implicitly transfer the collaborative knowledge across the federation by embedding the knowledge into the aggregated model or regularization. We observed that this implicit knowledge transfer fails to maximize the potential of each clientâ€™s empirical risk toward other clients. Based on our observation, in this work, we propose Personalized Global Federated Learning (PGFed), a novel personalized FL framework that enables each client to personalize its own global objective by explicitly and adaptively aggregating the empirical risks of itself and other clients. To avoid massive (Oâ€‹(N2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2O(N^{2})) communication overhead and potential privacy leakage while achieving this, each clientâ€™s risk is estimated through a first-order approximation for other clientsâ€™ adaptive risk aggregation. On top of PGFed, we develop a momentum upgrade, dubbed PGFedMo, to more efficiently utilize clientsâ€™ empirical risks. Our extensive experiments on four datasets under different federated settings show consistent improvements of PGFed over previous state-of-the-art methods. The code is publicly available at https://github.com/ljaiverson/pgfed.

1 Introduction

Recent years have witnessed the prosperity of federated learning (FL)Â [26, 14, 21, 39] in collaborative machine learning where the participating clients are subject to strict privacy rulesÂ [38]. Conventional FL aims to train a single global consensus model by orchestrating the participating clients with a central server. The most notable FL algorithm, FedAvgÂ [26], proceeds the training by exchanging between clients and server only the locally updated and globally aggregated model weights, leaving the private datasets intact. As a privacy-preserving machine learning technique, FL tremendously boosts new collaborations of decentralized parties in a number of areasÂ [41, 16, 24, 14].

Unfortunately, along with the emergence of conventional FL, new challenges have been posed in terms of systems and statistical heterogeneityÂ [21]. Systems heterogeneity addresses the variability of clientsâ€™ computation abilities, sizes of storage, or even the choices of model architecture due to different hardware constraints of the clients. Whereas statistical heterogeneity, the focus of this work, refers to the non-IID data among the clients, which could lead to non-guaranteed convergenceÂ [22, 30] and poor generalizability performanceÂ [32], even after fine-tuningÂ [13].

Over the years, the mediocre performance of conventional FL over heterogeneous data has not only promoted solutions that improve the single consensus model on top of FedAvgÂ [22, 1, 15, 20], a new paradigm, personalized FLÂ [36, 18], has emerged as well. In this paradigm, personalized models are allowed for each individual client. Some efforts in this direction focus on different personalized layers and optimization techniquesÂ [23, 5, 29]. Leveraging multi-taskÂ [44] or meta-learningÂ [10] is also shown to be beneficial in personalized FLÂ [34, 7, 3]. Other works include clustered FLÂ [9, 33, 31], interpolation of personalized modelsÂ [43, 25, 6], and fine-tuningÂ [28, 19, 40].

However, in most existing personalized FL algorithmsÂ [23, 5, 6, 12, 2, 7, 4, 28], the way in which the collaborative knowledge is transferred from the server to the clients is implicit. Here, we consider the collaborative knowledge as non-local information, such as the global objective of FedAvg, Fâ€‹(ğœ½)=âˆ‘ipiâ€‹Fiâ€‹(ğœ½)ğ¹ğœ½subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğœ½F({\bf\it\theta})=\sum_{i}p_{i}F_{i}({\bf\it\theta}), where ğœ½ğœ½{\bf\it\theta} is the global model and Fiâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–â‹…F_{i}(\cdot) represents client iğ‘–iâ€™s local objective whose weights are denoted as pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i}â€™s. In addition, we define â€œimplicitnessâ€ by defining its opposite side, â€œexplicitnessâ€, as a direct engagement with multiple clientsâ€™ empirical risks. For instance, updating the global model of FedAvg is explicit, where the direct engagement is achieved through communication. However, this can hardly be the case for updating clientsâ€™ personalized models, as it would take Oâ€‹(N2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2O(N^{2}) communication overhead to transmit each clientâ€™s personalized model to every client, assuming FedAvgâ€™s communication cost is Oâ€‹(N)ğ‘‚ğ‘O(N) over Nğ‘N clients. Consequently, most personalized FL algorithms implicitly transfer the collaborative knowledge from the server to the clients by embedding it into the aggregation of model weights or as different kinds of regularizers.

Why should we care about the â€œexplicitnessâ€, especially for updating the personalized models? Let us first assume all communication has zero cost, and, as an example, design a clientâ€™s explicit local objective as a â€œpersonalized global objectiveâ€ in the same form as the global objective of FedAvg (weighted sum of all clientsâ€™ risks), i.e. Fiâ€‹(ğœ½i)=fiâ€‹(ğœ½i)+Î¼/(Nâˆ’1)â€‹âˆ‘jâ‰ ifjâ€‹(ğœ½i)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğœ‡ğ‘1subscriptğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘–F_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})=f_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})+\mu/(N-1)\sum_{j\neq i}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{i}), where Fiâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–â‹…F_{i}(\cdot) and fiâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–â‹…f_{i}(\cdot) are client iğ‘–iâ€™s local objective and empirical risk, respectively, and Î¼ğœ‡\mu is a hyperparameter. By this means, the clients are no longer limited to implicitly acquiring the collaborative knowledge in an embedded (from the aggregated model weights) form.

The motivation behind this explicit design is that it facilitates the generalizability of the personalized models by directly penalizing their performance over other clientsâ€™ risks, contributing to more informative updates and therefore better local performance. On the other hand, an implicit personalization scheme embeds the non-local information into the aggregated model weights, preventing the clients from directly engaging with other clientsâ€™ risks.

We further demonstrate this motivation and the benefit of the explicit design by an empirical study: we personalize the output global model of FedAvg through S=6ğ‘†6S=6 steps of local gradient-based update, supposing that the Oâ€‹(Sâ€‹N2)ğ‘‚ğ‘†superscriptğ‘2O(SN^{2}) communication cost is affordable for now. We compare the exemplar explicit design of each clientâ€™s local objective with a simple implicit method, i.e. the local fine-tuning of FedAvg where each clientâ€™s local objective is only its own empirical risk (Fiâ€‹(ğœ½i)=fiâ€‹(ğœ½i)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–F_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})=f_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})).

The result of this empirical study are shown in Fig.Â 2. On CIFAR10 dataset with 100 heterogeneous clients, we observe that the explicit transfer of collaborative knowledge exhibits a stronger ability to adapt the model towards clientsâ€™ local data than the implicit counterpart, with a mean individual performance gain of 7.73% over local test data from the initial global model, 2.33% higher than that of an implicit personalization. Intriguing as the results may seem, how can we transfer this idea back to the communication-expensive real-world FL settings where acquiring all fjâ€‹(ğ›‰i)â€‹âˆ€i,jâˆˆ[N]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğ›‰ğ‘–for-allğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})\ \forall i,j\in[N] will cost Oâ€‹(N2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2O(N^{2}) communication overhead? Our solution is to estimate fjâ€‹(ğœ½i)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘–f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{i}) by approximation as shown in Fig.Â 1.

Based on the above observation, in this work, we propose Personalized Global Federated Learning (PGFed), a novel personalized FL framework that enables each client to personalize its own global objective by explicitly and adaptively aggregating the empirical risks of itself and other clients. To avoid massive communication overhead and potential privacy leakage, each clientâ€™s risk is estimated through a first-order approximation for other clientsâ€™ adaptive risk aggregation. Thereby, the clients are able to explicitly acquire the collaborative knowledge, and their personalized models can enjoy better generalizability. We summarize our contributions as follows:

  • â€¢

    We uncover that the explicitness of a personalized FL algorithm empowers itself with stronger adaptation ability. Based on this observation, we propose PGFed, a novel explicit personalized FL algorithm that frames the local objective of each client as a personalized global objective.

  • â€¢

    To the best of our knowledge, PGFed is the first work in the field to achieve explicit transfer of global collaborative knowledge among the clients, without introducing the seemingly unavoidable Oâ€‹(N2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2O(N^{2}) communication costs.

  • â€¢

    On top of PGFed, we develop a momentum upgrade, dubbed PGFedMo, to let the clients more efficiently utilize other clientsâ€™ empirical risks.

  • â€¢

    We evaluate PGFed and PGFedMo on four datasets under different FL settings. The results show that both algorithms outperform the compared state-of-the-art personalized FL methods, with up to 15.47% boost in accuracy.

2 Related Work

Federated Learning.

Federated learningÂ [14, 21, 39] focuses on training a global consensus model over a federation of clients with similar data. The most notable FL algorithm, FedAvgÂ [26], broadcast copies of the global model for local training and aggregate the updated copies as the new global model for the next round.

However, evidence began to accumulate in recent years that FedAvg is vulnerable towards data heterogeneity (non-IID data)Â [22, 32, 30, 13], which is the most common data distribution scenario in real-world FL. This vulnerability manifests itself as non-guaranteed convergenceÂ [30] and poor generalizability on test data after fine-tuningÂ [13], which can cost the incentives of participating clients.

To improve the performance of the global model, FedProxÂ [22] adds a proximal term to clientsâ€™ empirical risks to restrict the local update. FedDynÂ [1] introduces a dynamic regularizer to each client to align the global and local optima. SCAFFOLDÂ [15] corrects the local update by a control variate. And FedAlignÂ [27] focuses on local model generality rather than proximal restrictions. However, while effective, these global FL algorithms cannot systematically alleviate the data heterogeneity challenge.

Personalized Federated Learning.

Personalized FLÂ [36, 18] allows different models for different clients. This relaxation fundamentally mitigates the impact caused by the non-IID data. Methods in this category are the ones we mainly compare with in our experiments.

In this branch of work, [2, 23, 5] focus on aggregating different layers of the model. A recent work, FedBABUÂ [28], aggregates the feature extractor for a global model, and fine-tunes it for personalized models. Moreover, some works leverage multi-taskÂ [44] or meta-learningÂ [10] to learn the relationships between clientsâ€™ data distributionsÂ [34, 7, 3]. For instance, Per-FedAvgÂ [7] takes advantage of Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML)Â [8] and trains an easy-to-adapt initial shared model. Instead of training a different model per client, clustered FLÂ [9, 33] trains a distinct model for each cluster of similar clients. Interpolation of personalized models is also a popular directionÂ [43, 25, 6], where works concentrate more on a personalized way to aggregate the models from different clients.

In addition, some recent worksÂ [43, 25] afford to pay the Oâ€‹(N2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2O(N^{2}) communication cost to transmit the clientsâ€™ models to other clients, but their massive communication cost only benefits the model aggregation, instead of paying more attention on aggregating clientsâ€™ risks, which makes their algorithms fall into the implicit category. Another recent workÂ [4] bridges the personalized FL and global FL by training a global model with balanced risk and personalized adaptive predictors with empirical risk. However, it is still implicit, as the clients do not engage with othersâ€™ risks. In our work, we focus on an explicit way of personalization by introducing estimates of non-local empirical risks to each client without massive communication costs.

3 Problem Formulation

In this section, we formalize the problem of conventional and personalized FL, and further elaborate on the explicitness of personalized FL.

3.1 Conventional and Personalized FL

Conventional federated learning aims to train a global consensus model for a federation of clients with similar data. Take the most notable FL algorithm, FedAvgÂ [26], as an example. For a federation of Nğ‘N clients, the goal of FedAvg is to minimize the global objective defined as:

In FedAvg, the local objective Fiâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–â‹…F_{i}(\cdot) measures client iğ‘–iâ€™s empirical risk, i.e.

where ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} represents the data distribution, Î¾ksubscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜\xi_{k} is the kğ‘˜k-th data sample on client iğ‘–i, and the empirical risk fiâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–â‹…f_{i}(\cdot) is used to approximate the true risk on client iğ‘–i. Personalized FL relaxes the number of models. Compared to conventional FL, each client iğ‘–i is allowed to have its own personalized model ğœ½isubscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\bf\it\theta}_{i}, i.e. the goal of personalized FL is defined as:

where ğœ£ğœ£{\bf\it\Theta} is a dÃ—Nğ‘‘ğ‘d\times N matrix with dğ‘‘d being the number of dimensions of the model.

In addition, the number of participating clients (Nğ‘N) in FL is often largeÂ [14], and not all clients are able to participate in each federated round. Therefore, a subset of clients ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} with |ğ’®|=Mğ’®ğ‘€|\mathcal{S}|=M is selected for each round of training.

3.2 Implicit vs. Explicit Local Objective

As discussed in Sec.Â 1, we defined two types of ways for transferring the collaborative knowledge from the server to the clients for personalized FL algorithms. The explicit way updates the model with a direct engagement with multiple clientsâ€™ empirical risks. For instance, updating the global model of FedAvg achieves explicitness through communication. And in the empirical study (Fig.Â 2) in Sec.Â 1, we provided an example of explicit local objective as:

Fiâ€‹(ğœ½i)=fiâ€‹(ğœ½i)+Î¼(Nâˆ’1)â€‹âˆ‘jâ‰ ifjâ€‹(ğœ½i).subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğœ‡ğ‘1subscriptğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘–F_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})=f_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})+\frac{\mu}{(N-1)}\sum_{j\neq i}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{i}). (4)

It is obvious that engaging all fjâ€‹(ğœ½i)â€‹âˆ€i,jâˆˆ[N]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘–for-allğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})\ \forall i,j\in[N] to update the clientsâ€™ personalized models would take Oâ€‹(N2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2O(N^{2}) communication overhead. Therefore, most personalized FL algorithms implicitly transfer the collaborative knowledge by embedding it into the aggregation of model weights or as different regularizers.

One pitfall is that, to see whether a personalized FL algorithm manages to afford the Oâ€‹(N2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2O(N^{2}) communication overhead is NOT the criterion of checking its explicitness. Â [43, 25] are two recent works that did afford this communication cost on small federations, but since their personalized model updates do not directly involve other clientsâ€™ risks, both of these algorithms still fall into the implicit category.

In addition, note that the explicitness of a personalized FL algorithm does not prevent itself from simultaneously possessing characteristics from the implicit counterpart. For instance, in a personalized FL algorithm, taking the globally aggregated model as a round-beginning initialization for clientsâ€™ personalized models is an implicit characteristic that can co-exist with using Eq.Â 4 as an explicit personalization.

4 Method

In this section, we introduce the proposed algorithm, PGFed, in details. We clarify our global and local objectives, explain how we circumvent the massive communication cost, and introduce a momentum version of the algorithm, dubbed PGFedMo. The full procedure of PGFed is provided in AlgorithmÂ 1.

4.1 Objectives of PGFed

We adopt Eq.Â 3 as the global objective of PGFed. As mentioned in Sec.Â 3.2, an algorithm can simultaneously leverage characteristics from both explicit and implicit collaborative knowledge transfer. In each training round, we first implicitly transfer the collaborative knowledge to the clients by embedding it into the globally aggregated model, ğœ½gâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹bsubscriptğœ½ğ‘”ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘{\bf\it\theta}_{glob}, which serves as the round-beginning initialization for the clientsâ€™ personalized models.

To address the explicitness, we design the local objective as a personalized global objective in the same form as the global objective of FedAvg (weighted sum of every clientsâ€™ risks). Different from the previous exemplar design shown in Eq.Â 4, in PGFed, the local objective is defined as:

Fiâ€‹(ğœ½i,ğœ¶i)=fiâ€‹(ğœ½i)+Î¼â€‹âˆ‘jâˆˆ[N]Î±iâ€‹jâ€‹fjâ€‹(ğœ½i),subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğœ¶ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğœ‡subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘–F_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i},{\bf\it\alpha}_{i})=f_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})+\mu\sum_{j\in[N]}\alpha_{ij}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{i}), (5)

In this way, each client is able to personalize how much other clientsâ€™ risks should contribute to their own objective. Since Mğ‘€M clients are selected for every round, we initialize every as Î±iâ€‹j=1/Mâ€‹âˆ€i,jâˆˆ[N]formulae-sequencesubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘€for-allğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘\alpha_{ij}=1/M\ \forall i,j\in[N]. This new local objective slightly changes the global objective to:

where ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bf\it A} is an NÃ—Nğ‘ğ‘N\times N matrix with the iğ‘–i-th row being ğœ¶isubscriptğœ¶ğ‘–{\bf\it\alpha}_{i}.

Now, the question becomes: how can we overcome the massive communication cost to achieve explicit personalization? We answer this question in the next subsection.

4.2 Non-local Risk Estimation

In most real-world FL settings, Oâ€‹(N2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2O(N^{2}) communication cost is often not affordable, and PGFed is no exception. To achieve the explicitness without having to pay the unaffordable cost, we estimate the non-local empirical risks by first-order approximations. Specifically, we define the non-local empirical risk on client iğ‘–i as fjâ€‹(ğœ½i)â€‹âˆ€jâ‰ isubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘–for-allğ‘—ğ‘–f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})\ \forall j\neq i, and estimate this term by using Taylor expansion at ğœ½jsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—{\bf\it\theta}_{j}, i.e.

fjâ€‹(ğœ½i)â‰ˆfjâ€‹(ğœ½j)+âˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j)Tâ€‹(ğœ½iâˆ’ğœ½j),subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘—f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})\approx f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})+\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})^{T}({\bf\it\theta}_{i}-{\bf\it\theta}_{j}), (7)

where the higher-order terms are ignored. By plugging the approximation into Eq.Â 5, we have:

Fiâ€‹(ğœ½i,ğœ¶i)â‰ˆfiâ€‹(ğœ½i)+â„›aâ€‹uâ€‹x[N]â€‹(ğœ½i,ğœ¶i),subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğœ¶ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptâ„›ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğœ¶ğ‘–F_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i},{\bf\it\alpha}_{i})\approx f_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})+\mathcal{R}_{aux}^{[N]}({\bf\it\theta}_{i},{\bf\it\alpha}_{i}), (8)

â„›aâ€‹uâ€‹x[N]â€‹(ğœ½i,ğœ¶i)=Î¼â€‹âˆ‘jâˆˆ[N]Î±iâ€‹jâ€‹(fjâ€‹(ğœ½j)+âˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j)Tâ€‹(ğœ½iâˆ’ğœ½j)).superscriptsubscriptâ„›ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğœ¶ğ‘–ğœ‡subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘—\mathcal{R}_{aux}^{[N]}({\bf\it\theta}_{i},{\bf\it\alpha}_{i})=\mu\sum_{j\in[N]}\alpha_{ij}\left(f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})+\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})^{T}({\bf\it\theta}_{i}-{\bf\it\theta}_{j})\right).

 (9)

where we define â„›aâ€‹uâ€‹x[N]â€‹(â‹…)superscriptsubscriptâ„›ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘â‹…\mathcal{R}_{aux}^{[N]}(\cdot) as an auxiliary risk over all client jâˆˆ[N]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘j\in[N]. It is the existence of the auxiliary risk â„›aâ€‹uâ€‹x[N]â€‹(â‹…)superscriptsubscriptâ„›ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘â‹…\mathcal{R}_{aux}^{[N]}(\cdot) that makes the proposed algorithm an explicit personalization.

The intuition behind why the approximation might work lies in the regularization effect of our explicit personalization. As we personalize different clientsâ€™ models in the same form of global objective (Eq.Â 5), the non-local risks restrain the personalized model weights from ungoverned drifting. Compared to an implicit setting (e.g. FedAvgÂ [26]), the explicitly personalized models are more regularized, which enables the clients to train their personalized models in a more uniform direction. Therefore, as the regularization effect reduces the gaps between the personalized models, the first-order approximation is rewarded with a chance to shine in the proposed explicit personalization.

4.3 Gradient-based Update

In PGFed, the personalized models are updated through gradient-based optimizers such as stochastic gradient descent (SGD). In this section, we derive the gradient of the local objective of client iğ‘–i with respect to the personalized model ğœ½isubscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\bf\it\theta}_{i} and the personalized weights ğœ¶isubscriptğœ¶ğ‘–{\bf\it\alpha}_{i} for the non-local risks. Note that the gradient of the local objective is just the gradient of the local empirical risk plus the gradient of the auxiliary risk. Therefore, for the gradient w.r.t. ğœ½isubscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\bf\it\theta}_{i}, we have:

âˆ‡ğœ½iFi(ğœ½i,ğœ¶i)=âˆ‡ğœ½ifi(ğœ½i)+âˆ‡ğœ½iâ„›aâ€‹uâ€‹x[N](ğœ½i,ğœ¶i)=âˆ‡ğœ½ifiâ€‹(ğœ½i)+Î¼â€‹âˆ‘jâˆˆ[N]Î±iâ€‹jâ€‹âˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j)âŸg~[N].subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğœ¶ğ‘–subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptâ„›ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğœ¶ğ‘–subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptâŸğœ‡subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptg~delimited-[]ğ‘\begin{split}\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{i}}F_{i}(&{\bf\it\theta}_{i},{\bf\it\alpha}_{i})=\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{i}}f_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})+\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{i}}\mathcal{R}_{aux}^{[N]}({\bf\it\theta}_{i},{\bf\it\alpha}_{i})\\ &=\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{i}}f_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i})+\underbrace{\mu\sum_{j\in[N]}\alpha_{ij}\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})}_{\text{${\bf\it\tilde{\text{$g$}}}_{[N]}$}}.\end{split} (10)

Since the g~[N]subscriptg~delimited-[]ğ‘{\bf\it\tilde{\text{$g$}}}_{[N]}, the auxiliary gradient, is not related to ğœ½isubscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\bf\it\theta}_{i}, we can have it computed by the server by acquiring ğœ¶isubscriptğœ¶ğ‘–{\bf\it\alpha}_{i} from client iğ‘–i, and âˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j)subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j}) from client jğ‘—j.

For the gradient w.r.t. ğœ¶isubscriptğœ¶ğ‘–{\bf\it\alpha}_{i}, similarly, we have:

âˆ‡Î±iâ€‹jFiâ€‹(ğœ½i,ğœ¶i)=Î¼â€‹(fjâ€‹(ğœ½j)+âˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j)Tâ€‹(ğœ½iâˆ’ğœ½j))=Î¼â€‹(fjâ€‹(ğœ½j)âˆ’âˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j)Tâ€‹ğœ½j)âŸgÎ±(1)+Î¼â€‹âˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j)Tâ€‹ğœ½iâŸgÎ±(2).subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğœ¶ğ‘–ğœ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptâŸğœ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼1subscriptâŸğœ‡subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼2\begin{split}&\nabla_{\alpha_{ij}}F_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i},{\bf\it\alpha}_{i})=\mu\left(f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})+\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})^{T}({\bf\it\theta}_{i}-{\bf\it\theta}_{j})\right)\\ &=\underbrace{\mu\left(f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})-\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})^{T}{\bf\it\theta}_{j}\right)}_{\text{$g_{\alpha}^{(1)}$}}+\underbrace{\mu\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})^{T}{\bf\it\theta}_{i}}_{\text{$g_{\alpha}^{(2)}$}}.\end{split} (11)

As shown in Eq.Â 11, this gradient can be split into two components: the first term, gÎ±(1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼1g_{\alpha}^{(1)}, is a scalar purely associated with client jğ‘—j, which can be uploaded from client jğ‘—j with little cost; the second term is an interaction between the gradient of client jğ‘—j and the personalized model of client iğ‘–i. To accurately acquire gÎ±(2)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼2g_{\alpha}^{(2)} term itself would, again, cost Oâ€‹(N2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2O(N^{2}) communication overhead. Therefore, we approximate this term by an average, gÂ¯[N]subscriptgÂ¯delimited-[]ğ‘{\bf\it\bar{\text{$g$}}}_{[N]}, computed by the server, i.e.

gÎ±(2)â‰ˆgÂ¯[N]Tâ€‹ğœ½i=Î¼Nâ€‹(âˆ‘jâˆˆ[N]âˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j))Tâ€‹ğœ½i.superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼2superscriptsubscriptgÂ¯delimited-[]ğ‘ğ‘‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğœ‡ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–g_{\alpha}^{(2)}\approx{\bf\it\bar{\text{$g$}}}_{[N]}^{T}{\bf\it\theta}_{i}=\frac{\mu}{N}\left(\sum_{j\in[N]}\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})\right)^{T}{\bf\it\theta}_{i}. (12)

Although transmitting gÂ¯[N]subscriptgÂ¯delimited-[]ğ‘{\bf\it\bar{\text{$g$}}}_{[N]} can be costly, and it is possible for the server to transmit the scalar value of gÎ±(2)â‰ˆgÂ¯[N]Tâ€‹ğœ½isuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼2superscriptsubscriptgÂ¯delimited-[]ğ‘ğ‘‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–g_{\alpha}^{(2)}\approx{\bf\it\bar{\text{$g$}}}_{[N]}^{T}{\bf\it\theta}_{i}, we argue that it is not ideal to directly send this scalar to client iğ‘–i, because the calculations of gÎ±(2)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼2g_{\alpha}^{(2)} and âˆ‡Î±iâ€‹jFiâ€‹(ğœ½i,ğœ¶i)subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğœ½ğ‘–subscriptğœ¶ğ‘–\nabla_{\alpha_{ij}}F_{i}({\bf\it\theta}_{i},{\bf\it\alpha}_{i}) are during the process of updating ğœ½isubscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\bf\it\theta}_{i}. And since calculating gÎ±(2)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼2g_{\alpha}^{(2)} involves ğœ½isubscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\bf\it\theta}_{i}, it would be more reasonable to treat gÂ¯[N]Tâ€‹ğœ½isuperscriptsubscriptgÂ¯delimited-[]ğ‘ğ‘‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\bf\it\bar{\text{$g$}}}_{[N]}^{T}{\bf\it\theta}_{i} as a variable and have it computed by client iğ‘–i locally, rather than treating it as a constant computed it by the server.

In the descriptions of the proposed algorithm above, we did not elaborate on how the client selection procedure would affect the auxiliary risks of each client. As mentioned in Sec.Â 4.1, in each round tğ‘¡t, a subset of clients, ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\mathcal{S}_{t} with |ğ’®t|=Msubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡ğ‘€|\mathcal{S}_{t}|=M, are selected for the training. We, therefore, slightly modify the auxiliary risk from â„›aâ€‹uâ€‹x[N]superscriptsubscriptâ„›ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘\mathcal{R}_{aux}^{[N]} to â„›aâ€‹uâ€‹xğ’®tsuperscriptsubscriptâ„›ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘¥subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\mathcal{R}_{aux}^{\mathcal{S}_{t}}. This change will subsequently affect the scope of two terms, namely the auxiliary gradient g~[N]subscriptg~delimited-[]ğ‘{\bf\it\tilde{\text{$g$}}}_{[N]} w.r.t. ğœ½isubscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\bf\it\theta}_{i} (changed to g~ğ’®tsubscriptg~subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\bf\it\tilde{\text{$g$}}}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}), and gÂ¯[N]subscriptgÂ¯delimited-[]ğ‘{\bf\it\bar{\text{$g$}}}_{[N]}, a portion of the gradient w.r.t. Î±iâ€‹jsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha_{ij} (changed to gÂ¯ğ’®tsubscriptgÂ¯subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\bf\it\bar{\text{$g$}}}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}). We formally define these two new terms below:

g~ğ’®t=Î¼â€‹âˆ‘jâˆˆğ’®tÎ±iâ€‹jâ€‹âˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j),subscriptg~subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡ğœ‡subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—{\bf\it\tilde{\text{$g$}}}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}=\mu\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\alpha_{ij}\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j}), (13)
gÂ¯ğ’®t=Î¼Mâ€‹âˆ‘jâˆˆğ’®tâˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j).subscriptgÂ¯subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡ğœ‡ğ‘€subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—{\bf\it\bar{\text{$g$}}}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}=\frac{\mu}{M}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j}). (14)

To sum up, the auxiliary risk â„›aâ€‹uâ€‹xğ’®tsuperscriptsubscriptâ„›ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘¥subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\mathcal{R}_{aux}^{\mathcal{S}_{t}} on a client ultimately results in downloading two server-aggregated gradients g~ğ’®tsubscriptg~subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\bf\it\tilde{\text{$g$}}}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}} and gÂ¯ğ’®tsubscriptgÂ¯subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\bf\it\bar{\text{$g$}}}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}} (and a negligible scalar gÎ±(1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼1g_{\alpha}^{(1)}). Note that while achieving the explicitness, this server aggregation makes it infeasible for the client to separate other clientsâ€™ gradient for inferring their data, which protects the clientsâ€™ privacy.

4.4 PGFed with Momentum (PGFedMo)

When considering the client selection for each round, the auxiliary risk changed from â„›aâ€‹uâ€‹x[N]superscriptsubscriptâ„›ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘\mathcal{R}_{aux}^{[N]} to â„›aâ€‹uâ€‹xğ’®tsuperscriptsubscriptâ„›ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘¥subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\mathcal{R}_{aux}^{\mathcal{S}_{t}}. This reduces the number of clientsâ€™ risks involved in the calculation of auxiliary risk from Nğ‘N to Mğ‘€M, which could be a huge loss of information. To compensate for this loss, each client maintains g~ğ’®tisuperscriptsubscriptg~subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bf\it\tilde{\text{$g$}}}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}^{i} locally, and every time when the client is selected, it updates its local auxiliary gradient g~ğ’®tisuperscriptsubscriptg~subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bf\it\tilde{\text{$g$}}}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}^{i} in a momentum manner, i.e.

g~ğ’®tiâ†(1âˆ’Î²)â€‹g~ğ’®tiâ€‹(downloaded)+Î²â€‹g~ğ’®tiâ€‹(previous)â†superscriptsubscriptg~subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡ğ‘–1ğ›½superscriptsubscriptg~subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡ğ‘–downloadedğ›½superscriptsubscriptg~subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡ğ‘–previous{\bf\it\tilde{\text{$g$}}}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}^{i}\leftarrow(1-\beta){\bf\it\tilde{\text{$g$}}}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}^{i}(\text{downloaded})+\beta{\bf\it\tilde{\text{$g$}}}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}^{i}(\text{previous}) (15)

In this way, the clients are able to carry the auxiliary gradient, without having to discard the collaborative knowledge from the Nâˆ’Mğ‘ğ‘€N-M clients each round. We summarize the proposed algorithm in AlgorithmÂ 1.

5 Experiments

5.1 Experimental Setup

Compared methods.

We evaluate the proposed algorithms, PGFed and PGFedMo, against a number of state-of-the-art FL algorithms, including two global FL algorithms: the leading FedAvg and FedDyn that uses a dynamically regularized local training, and nine personalized FL algorithms: pFedME which conducts personalization with Moreau Envelopes; FedFomo and APFL which interpolates personalized models by interpolation; FedRep, LG-FedAvg, and FedPer which personalize different layers of the model; Per-FedAvg which leverages meta-learning to learn an initial shared model, and one-step fine-tuning over local data; FedRoD which trains a global model with balanced risk and personalized adaptive predictors with empirical risk; and FedBABU which focuses on global representation learning and personalize the model by fine-tuning for one epoch.

Datasets.

We conduct experiments on four datasets. In the main content, we report the results on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100Â [17], and we leave the experiments on OrganAMNISTÂ [42] and Office-homeÂ [37] dataset in the supplementary materials. Following Â [11], we use Dirichlet distribution with Î±=0.3ğ›¼0.3\alpha=0.3 to partition the dataset into heterogeneous settings with 25, 50, and 100 clients. For each setting, each clientâ€™s local training and test datasets are under the same distribution. We report the mean top-1 personalized accuracy by averaging the local test accuracies over all clients.

Implementation details.

We adopt the same convolutional neural network (CNN)â€™s architecture as in FedAvg for all the compared methods. There are 2 convolutional layers with 32, and 64 5Ã—5555\times 5 kernels and 2 fully connected layers with 512 hidden units in this architecture. For the methods that involve representation learning, we split the model into a feature extractor with the first three layers, and a classifier with the last layer. We use a stochastic gradient descent (SGD) optimizer for every method with a fixed momentum of 0.9. Each method is trained on the dataset for 300 federated rounds. For each federated setting, the client sample rate is set to 25%, and the local training epochs is set to 5. The learning rate is tuned from {0.1, 0.01, 0.001, 0.0001} for every method. For PGFed, the coefficient for the auxiliary risk, Î¼ğœ‡\mu, is tuned from {0.1, 0.05, 0.01, 0.005, 0.001}. For PGFedMo, the momentum, Î²ğ›½\beta, is tuned from {0.2, 0.5, 0.8}. More details about hyperparameters values are included in the Supplementary Material.

5.2 Main Results and Analysis

We report the mean and standard deviation of three different seeds for each setting. As shown in Tab.Â 1, our method achieves the highest mean accuracies under all settings. With large data heterogeneity using Dir(0.3) as in our experiments, local training can often achieve better performance than participating in global FL. As the number of clients increases, the clients benefit more from FL, since local training is more likely to overfit on the small local datasets. Within the comparison of personalized FL algorithms, PGFed and the momentum upgrade, PGFedMo, enjoy performance improvements by up to 15.47% in accuracy (CIFAR100 with 25 clients), outperforming the methods that personalize different components of the model such as FedRep, LG-FedAvg, and FedPer, and even with the fine-tuning in FedBABU and the meta-learning Per-FedAvg, as well as the interpolation methods such as APFL and FedFomo. With the global model and the personalized adapter, FedRod benefits the local performance by the most within the baselines, yet was still exceeded by PGFed and PGFedMo by up to 4.63%percent4.634.63\% (on CIFAR100 with 50 clients). For PGFed, the momentum upgrade, PGFedMo, further boosts its performance since more clientsâ€™ risk is included in the clientsâ€™ auxiliary risks with the momentum update.

In Tab.Â 2, we show the convergence speed of the personalized algorithms by reporting the round numbers at which the algorithms achieve 70% mean top-1 personalized accuracy on CIFAR10. For each setting, we set the algorithm that takes the most round to reach 70% as â€œ1.0Ã—1.0\timesâ€, and find that the proposed PGFed and PGFedMo consistently present a decent amount of speedup from the compared personalized FL algorithms. Among the six compared personalized FL algorithms, FedPer has the fastest convergence speed, due to the smaller size of the globally aggregated model component (only the feature extractor layers are aggregated in FedPer). Although not fastest, PGFed and PGFedMo still have an average of 3.7Ã—3.7\times speed up in convergence rate, while enjoying the best performance in accuracy.

Besides the overall performance and the convergence speed, we take a micro-perspective to examine the individual performance gain over the Local training. Specifically, we concentrate on the statistics of the individual performance gain across the federation of clients, which can indicate the fairness performance of the algorithms. For instance, the individual gain with a high standard deviation might indicate that the high performance gains on some clients come with a sacrifice over the performance gains (little or negative gains) on other clients. In Tab.Â 3 and 4, we show that while enjoying the highest mean individual gains under each setting, the standard deviations of both PGFed and PGFedMo are reasonably small as well, suggesting a fair boost of performance from every client. We attribute the high mean and low standard deviation merit of the proposed algorithms to the explicitness of our design of local objectives. Although clientsâ€™ local objectives are personalized, the explicitness enables the clientsâ€™ local objectives to be of the same form (weighted sum of multiple empirical risks). And each clientâ€™s local empirical risk takes roughly 1/(1+Î¼)11ğœ‡1/(1+\mu) of its own objective, which is the same for every client, hence the similar individual performance gain and fair federated personalization.

5.3 Visualization of coefficient matrix ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bf\it A}

We investigate the coefficient matrix, ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bf\it A}, of Î±iâ€‹jsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha_{ij}â€™s in PGFed (recall that Î±iâ€‹jsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha_{ij} is the coefficient of client jğ‘—jâ€™s empirical risk on client iğ‘–i). Specifically, we visualize the change of all Î±iâ€‹jâ€‹âˆ€i,jâˆˆ[N]subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—for-allğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘\alpha_{ij}\ \forall i,j\in[N] on CIFAR10 with 25 clients. As a refresher, ğœ¶isubscriptğœ¶ğ‘–{\bf\it\alpha}_{i}, the iğ‘–i-th row of ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bf\it A}, represents the vector of weights indicating how much client iğ‘–i values other clientsâ€™ risks. The jğ‘—j-th column of ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bf\it A}, ğ‘¨jsubscriptğ‘¨ğ‘—{\bf\it A}_{j}, represents the vector of weights indicating how much client jğ‘—j is valuable towards other clientsâ€™ risks.

In theory, without the first-order estimation (see Eq.Â 5), the gradient of Î±iâ€‹jsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha_{ij} equals Î¼â€‹fjâ€‹(ğœ½i)ğœ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘–\mu f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{i}), which is non-negative. This suggests that Î±iâ€‹jsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha_{ij} will always converge to 0 given enough time, i.e. âˆ€i,jâˆˆ[N],limtâ†’âˆÎ±iâ€‹j=0formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—0\forall i,j\in[N],\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\alpha_{ij}=0. However, since fjâ€‹(ğœ½i)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘–f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{i}) is estimated through Taylor expansion, and higher order terms are omitted, in practice of PGFed, Î±iâ€‹jsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha_{ij} has a chance to increase (pink and red blocks in Fig.Â 3(a)), or decreases more slowly (light blue in Fig.Â 3(a)), as long as client iğ‘–iâ€™s local objective decreases. Therefore, whether Î±iâ€‹jsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha_{ij} changes in the positive or negative directions depends on whether fjâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—â‹…f_{j}(\cdot) can be â€œhelpfulâ€ to reduce the local objective of client iğ‘–i as a result of optimization.

We quantify this â€œhelpâ€ that client jğ‘—j can offer by Î”â€‹ğ‘¨jÂ¯Â¯Î”subscriptğ‘¨ğ‘—\overline{\Delta{\bf\it A}_{j}}: the average change of the jğ‘—j-th column of ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bf\it A} (i.e. Î±iâ€‹jâ€‹âˆ€iâˆˆ[N]subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘\alpha_{ij}\ \forall i\in[N]), and quantify the â€œhelpâ€ that client iğ‘–i needs by Î”â€‹ğœ¶iÂ¯Â¯Î”subscriptğœ¶ğ‘–\overline{\Delta{\bf\it\alpha}_{i}}: the average change of the iğ‘–i-th row of ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bf\it A} (i.e. Î±iâ€‹jâ€‹âˆ€jâˆˆ[N]subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—for-allğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘\alpha_{ij}\ \forall j\in[N]). An intuitive indicator of this â€œhelpâ€ is the number of local training samples. From the perspective of client jğ‘—j (the helper), larger local training set of client jğ‘—j should be able to make its empirical risk more likely to be helpful to other clients. From the perspective of client iğ‘–i (the helpee), smaller training set of client iğ‘–i should require more help from others. Therefore, ideally, Î”â€‹ğ‘¨jÂ¯Â¯Î”subscriptğ‘¨ğ‘—\overline{\Delta{\bf\it A}_{j}} and Î”â€‹ğœ¶iÂ¯Â¯Î”subscriptğœ¶ğ‘–\overline{\Delta{\bf\it\alpha}_{i}} should be positively and negatively correlated to the number of local training samples, respectively. This is verified as a finding in the resulting ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bf\it A} of PGFed in Fig.Â 3(b) and Fig.Â 3(c).

5.4 Generalizability to New Clients

In real-world FL settings, it is possible that some clients did not participate in the FL training, but wish to have a model that could quickly adapt to their local data. This makes it especially desirable for a personalized FL algorithm to possess excellent adaptive ability. By design, PGFed is able to generate a global model as a side product (line 16 of AlgorithmÂ 1). Therefore, we simulate such a setting and study the generalizability of our global model, and compare it against several baseline algorithms (global and personalized) that also produce the global model. Specifically, we simulate this setting by conducting FL over 80 clients randomly selected from 100 clients on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 datasets, and fine-tuning the trained global model on the rest 20 new clients. Besides Local training, we compare PGFed and PGFedMo with FedAvg and Per-FedAvg, whose goal is to train an easy-to-adapt model. The results are shown in Fig.Â 4.

Since the local fine-tuning on the 20 new clients is a standard vanilla training with SGD for all five compared methods, a high mean personalized accuracy directly indicates stronger overall generalizability of the global model (for FL algorithms), especially when the starting mean accuracies (before fine-tuning) are roughly the same. From Fig.Â 4, we can see that the Local trained models do not generalize well on local test data, since the size of the local dataset is likely to be small with a 100-client setting. For the FL algorithms, PGFedMo achieves the best mean personalized accuracy, which shows strong generalizability of the global model of the proposed algorithm thanks to the explicit design. While not being the main focus, the high generalizability of PGFedâ€™s and PGFedMoâ€™s global models shown on new clients also indicates the modelsâ€™ strong adaptiveness in the original personalized FL task.

6 Conclusion and Discussion

In this work, we discovered that a personalized FL algorithmâ€™s explicitness enhances modelsâ€™ generalizability, resulting in better local performance. Based on our observations, we proposed, PGFed, and its momentum upgrade, PGFedMo. Both algorithms explicitly transfer the collaborative knowledge across the clients by formulating their local objectives as personalized global objectives. This is achieved without introducing the seemingly unavoidable massive communication costs or potential privacy risk. Our extensive experiments demonstrated the improvements of the proposed algorithms over state-of-the-art methods on four datasets under different heterogeneous FL settings.

We expect the proposed framework to be extended in different directions. First, since the proposed framework is agnostic, it can be potentially combined with existing implicit FL algorithms such as Â [23, 5, 6, 2, 4, 28]. Moreover, although the proposed work manages to avoid the Oâ€‹(N2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2O(N^{2}) communication overhead, since it still costs roughly 2.5Ã—2.5\times the communication of FedAvg, a more communication-efficient method is also worth investigations. We leave these directions for future work.

Appendix A Overview

We organize the supplementary material as follows:

  • â€¢

    In AppendixÂ B, we report additional results and analyses of PGFed and conduct experiments on two other datasets, OrganAMNISTÂ [42] & Office-homeÂ [37] with different FL settings.

  • â€¢

    In AppendixÂ C, we compare the local computational speed of the proposed algorithm, PGFed, with the baselines that achieved top performance in the experiments on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100.

  • â€¢

    In AppendixÂ D, we further propose PGFed-CE, a variation on top of PGFed to reduce both the communication and the computation cost simultaneously.

  • â€¢

    In AppendixÂ E, we report details in hyperparameters regarding our experiments.

Appendix B Additional Experiments and Analyses

B.1 Convergence Behavior

We empirically study the convergence behavior of PGFed and the baselines that achieved high performance on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100. For each method, we plot its mean personalized test accuracy on CIFAR10 for the first 150 rounds of training under 25-, 50- and 100-client settings, as shown in Fig.Â 5.

From the results, we can see that, while achieving the highest accuracy performance, PGFed is also able to consistently converge faster than most of the baselines that reach high accuracies. Fast as it is under these settings, one limitation of PGFed is that the update of Î±iâ€‹jsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha_{ij} in PGFed only happens when client iğ‘–i and client jğ‘—j are selected in two consecutive rounds (client jğ‘—j is selected exactly one round before client iğ‘–i), which happens by chance. Therefore, this randomness might slightly limit the overall convergence behavior of PGFed, but it is the existence of Î±iâ€‹jsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha_{ij}â€™s that enables the adaptive personalization of how much each client values other clientsâ€™ empirical risks, hence the higher accuracy.

B.2 Experiments on Other Datasets

To further evaluate the effectiveness of PGFed with different types of data and different FL settings, we conduct experiments on two more datasets: OrganAMNISTÂ [42] and Office-homeÂ [37]. OrganAMNIST is a medical imaging dataset of abdominal CT images with 11 classes. Office-homeÂ [37] contains four domains (Art, Clipart, Product, and Real World) of images depicting 65 classes of objects typically found in Office and Home settings.

For OrganAMNIST, we adopt three settings with different numbers (25, 50, 100) of clients. For the 50- and 100-client settings, we follow the same setting as in the experiments on CIFAR10/CIFAR100, and use the Dirichlet distribution with Î±=0.3ğ›¼0.3\alpha=0.3 (Dir(0.3)) and 25% client sample rate for each round. For the 25-client setting, we reduce the heterogeneity in the dataset via Dir(1.0) distribution, and use a higher client sample rate (50%) to simulate a situation more similar to cross-silo FL settings. For Office-home, we adopt a 20-client setting, where each domain contains 5 clients. The non-IIDness in each domain is achieved by Dir(0.3). The mean personalized test accuracies of each domain and over the whole federation are reported. We compare the proposed PGFed and PGFedMo against Local, FedAvg, and the personalized FL baselines that achieved high performance in previous experiments on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100. The results are shown in Tab.Â 5 and Tab.Â 6.

For OrganAMNIST, PGFed and PGFedMo achieve the best performance under all three settings. In addition, the proposed algorithms do not have an obvious drop in the performance from the less heterogeneous 25-client setting to 50-client and 100-client settings. This is not the case for many other personalized FL baselines (FedPer, Per-FedAvg, FedRoD, and FedBABU). Moreover, FedAvg achieves excellent performance on OrganAMNIST due to the similarity of clientsâ€™ images (see Fig.Â 6). Since the Dirichlet distribution can only differ the clients in Pâ€‹(y)ğ‘ƒğ‘¦P(y), the label distribution, instead of Pâ€‹(x|y)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¥ğ‘¦P(x|y), the distribution of the images given the label, a simple averaging might work just fine on OrganAMNIST compared with other datasets. On the contrary, Office-home is a dataset that addresses different Pâ€‹(x|y)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¥ğ‘¦P(x|y) since for this dataset, even the images within the same class can be dramatically different if they belong to clients from different domains, which is indicated by the worse performance of FedAvg than Local training. Results on this dataset also show that PGFed and PGFedMo consistently outperform most of the compared methods in each domain, and achieve the highest mean accuracies over all domains, demonstrating their superiority over all the compared methods.

Appendix C Comparison in Local Computational Speed

In this section, we study the local computational speed of PGFed and the baselines that achieved top performance in the experiments. We measure the local computational speed by the number of images each method can process per second, and report the local computational speed of the methods in Tab.Â 7 on CIFAR10 with 50 clients and a batch size of 128, using an NVIDIA Tesla V100 GPU and an Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6248 CPU.

From the results, we can see that PGFed not only reaches high accuracy, but has a relatively high computational speed as well. With a batch size of 128, PGFed reaches a speed equivalent to 88.48% of FedAvgâ€™s speeds. PGFedMo is slightly slower than PGFed due to the momentum update of the auxiliary gradient. However, for some of the compared methods that also achieve high accuracy, their computational speed is compromised by around 50% (compared to FedAvg): APFL needs to train a global model and a local adapter, while Per-FedAvg leverages meta-learning which is a bi-level optimization problem. These methods either train two models or conduct twice gradient descent for each iteration. FedRoD trains a global model and a local classifier, which ends up being 8.13% faster than PGFed. For PGFed, the extra local computation (over FedAvg) happens at the addition of the gradients from both the local empirical risk and the auxiliary risk, and at the update of ğœ¶isubscriptğœ¶ğ‘–{\bf\it\alpha}_{i} where a dot product of vectorized models is calculated (see Eq.(12) in the main paper).

Appendix D PGFed-CE, a More Communication- and Computation-efficient PGFed

As mentioned in Sec. 6 of the main paper, although PGFed manages to circumvent the seemingly unavoidable Oâ€‹(N2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘2O(N^{2}) communication cost, and achieve asymptotically the same communication cost as FedAvg (Oâ€‹(N)ğ‘‚ğ‘O(N)), since each client is required to download three and upload two models/gradients per round, on average the communication cost is still high (roughly 2.5 times as much as that of FedAvg).

In this section, we provide a more communication-efficient version of PGFed, dubbed PGFed-CE that downloads one less gradient from the server. In Sec. 4 of the main paper, we mentioned that gÎ±(2)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼2g_{\alpha}^{(2)}, a portion of the gradient of the local objective in terms of ğœ¶isubscriptğœ¶ğ‘–{\bf\it\alpha}_{i} in PGFed, could be computed on the server instead of the client. This is because

gÎ±(2)=Î¼â€‹âˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j)Tâ€‹ğœ½i,superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼2ğœ‡subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘–g_{\alpha}^{(2)}=\mu\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})^{T}{\bf\it\theta}_{i}, (16)

and the server has both âˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j)subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j}) from the previous round and the current round global model as the initialization of ğœ½isubscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\bf\it\theta}_{i}. Therefore, it is possible to treat gÎ±(2)=Î¼â€‹âˆ‡ğœ½jfjâ€‹(ğœ½j)Tâ€‹ğœ½gâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹bsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼2ğœ‡subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptğœ½ğ‘”ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘g_{\alpha}^{(2)}=\mu\nabla_{{\bf\it\theta}_{j}}f_{j}({\bf\it\theta}_{j})^{T}{\bf\it\theta}_{glob} as a constant computed by the server, where the global model is used as an estimation of ğœ½isubscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\bf\it\theta}_{i} for the whole round. Since Î±isubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–\alpha_{i} should change adaptively according to the change of ğœ½isubscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\bf\it\theta}_{i} during local training, using the global model as a fixed estimation is not ideal. Nonetheless, this variation saves the communication cost by the size of one gradient (gÂ¯ğ’®tsubscriptgÂ¯subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\bf\it\bar{\text{$g$}}}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}) from clientsâ€™ round-beginning download, that was needed to adaptively compute ğœ¶isubscriptğœ¶ğ‘–{\bf\it\alpha}_{i} locally, which also slightly saves the local computation.

We name this more communication- and computation-efficient variant of PGFed as PGFed-CE. In PGFed-CE, each client is now required to download two, instead of three, models/gradients per round. Consequently, on average, the communication cost is reduced from 2.5 to 2 times as much as that of FedAvg. In addition, we follow AppendixÂ C and report the local computational speed of PGFed-CE and its performance on CIFAR10 with 50 clients in Tab.Â 7. As expected, besides the reduced communication cost, PGFed-CE also simultaneously increases the local computational speed with little drop in the accuracy.

Appendix E Hyperparameters

Besides the hyperparameter tuning of PGFed reported in Sec. 4.1 in the main paper, we further report the hyperparameter tuning of the compared baselines in this section. The learning rate of all baselines is tuned from {0.1, 0.01, 0.001, 0.0001}. For FedDyn, we tuned the Î±ğ›¼\alpha in {0.1, 0.01, 0.001}. For APFL, the Î±ğ›¼\alpha is tuned in {0.25, 0.50, 0.75}. For Per-FedAvg, the two learning rates for each step are selected from {0.1, 0.01, 0.001, 0.0001}, which is the same for FedBABUâ€™s learning rates for federated training and fine-tuning step.
